thread.title: Dizzy’s advice to Aussies after best ever away win
thread.title_full: Dizzy’s advice to Aussies after best ever away win

title: Dizzy’s advice to Aussies after best ever away win
text:
Aussies claim 333 run win 2:36 Jason Gillespie hails Australia’s win in Pune as country’s greatest performance overseas  05pm by Staff writers Source: FOX SPORTS JASON Gillespie has hailed Australia’s win over India in the first Test as the country’s greatest ever overseas performance but would still be tempted to call-up Glenn Maxwell for game two. 
Having gone into the Border-Gavaskar series as huge underdogs, Steve Smith’s men hammered India by 333 runs in two-and-a-half days on a rank turner in Pune, ending the host’s 19-Test unbeaten streak. 
“It’s one of, if not the, best performance by an Australian side overseas pretty much ever,” Gillespie told EON Sports. “With everything that was going against them, I think it’s right up there.” 
That’s high praise from the former fast bowler considering he was a key part of the Australian outfit (20 wickets at 16.15) that famously triumphed 2-1 over India in India in 2004.

ANALYSIS: The big questions facing Aussies after perfect Pune Jason Gillespie (left) took 20 wickets when Australia last won a Test series in India. Source: Getty Images 
The Adelaide Strikers coach cannot see Australia making any changes from the XI that won so comprehensively in Pune, but believes Maxwell is worth looking at. 
The all-rounder, who has not played a Test since 2014, has a healthy first-class average of 39.60 and is highly rated in India due to his ability to take the attack to the spinners. 
“(Mitchell Marsh has) probably done enough to hang on but if they feel they can get away with two seamers I’d be tempted to potentially play someone like Glenn Maxwell who is a fine player of spin. I think he’s an underrated long form player. 
“I think on these surfaces he can be quite fearless and take the attack to the Indian spinners.” 
Marsh did not bowl a single over in Pune but with Bangalore’s pitch expected to be a far more traditional Indian wicket – favouring the batsmen over the first three days before breaking up – Gillespie does not believe Australia will risk dropping the seam-bowling all-rounder. 
Gillespie was a part of the Australian squad that last won a series in India in 2004. Just like the current series, the Australians won their first match of that tour and the 41-year-old is confident Smith’s outfit are good enough to capitalise on the same opening. 
“India have to make the play here, and they have to go out and take some risks and be ultra-positive. Australia just need to play and take the games deep. 
“The simpler the Australian boys keep it and the longer the games go, the Indians will start to panic a little bit, and they’ll start to try to create things when they’re not there and that’s where their mistakes will come in. 
“If we just stick to our disciplines and stick to our patience, follow that process we’ll be well in the game.” Kohli plays costly leave 0:31 
Steve O’Keefe made the most of an old fashioned Bunsen burner in game one, finishing with match-figures of 12-70, orchestrating a stunning first-innings collapse that saw the Indians lose seven wickets for 11 runs. O’Keefe’s figures were the 11th best of any Test bowler in India and the best ever by a touring spinner. They were also 10th best by an Australian anywhere. 
Despite this, Aussie provocateur Harbhajan Singh remains unconvinced of the left-arm finger spinner’s quality. 
“I will have to see him bowl on a good Test match wicket. Not this one. Till then, I will reserve my comments,” Harbhajan told the Indian Express. 
Virat Kohli was similarly dismissive of O’Keefe’s performance, pinning the humiliating loss on India’s batting and not Australia’s bowling. 
“If you don’t apply yourself, any bowling attack can look dangerous,” Kohli quipped, when asked about O’Keefe’s 12-wicket match haul. 
But Gillespie is confident O’Keefe is capable of causing India’s batsmen trouble on flatter tracks than the one dished up in Pune. 
“He’s consistently hitting a spot on the pitch which is challenging the batsman to make a decision,” he said. 
“He always keeps the stumps in the game, that’s the thing with Steve O’Keefe, he keeps the stumps in play at all time.”
